text: This is definitely not a supported configuration for HubSpot and can lead to a lot of problems including having your site blocked due to what appear to be an attack from a single IP (your proxy)
It will also slow down your site since you’re not using our CDN
^ I feel you.  I don’t wanna do it either.  they won’t put site on CMS, looking for best options.
I like that idea!

We have a client, Gliffy (SASS), using AWS and they attempted and realized that it wasn’t worth it.  If you are worried about SEO on a subdomain for blogs, or separation, I have a wonderful email I typed up that goes into this
I can share if you like <@U2SJA29B4>

<@U25PYL3Q8> happy to receive that email Nicholas… thanks.  
I have some data on this myself but always good to have another opinion.
my response was to this question specifically: Can one of you help answer the question/never-ending-debate on whether putting content on subdomain effects SEOs? Not sure where we stand there...

My short response would be:
Google has said that they treat content on a subdomain vs subfolder roughly equal (Matt Cutts from Google: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_MswMYk05tk> note, most likely Rand’s whiteboard will show up as the second video after this plays). It is still believed in general thought that subfolder is better than subdomain (Rand Fishkin says: <https://moz.com/blog/subdomains-vs-subfolders-rel-canonical-vs-301-how-to-structure-links-optimally-for-seo-whiteboard-friday>). We have seen better results moving a blog from a subdomain to a subfolder with Decisiv, an account that I worked on that benefited from a move from a subdomain to a subfolder about a year and a half ago.

The real item to think about this, in the grand scheme of an inbound website/methodology:
Overall landing pages in general don’t rank well from an organic standpoint because they don’t really have “content” in them. (This is a reason for ungated content, as the content is on the page and will rank better). In the grand scheme of things, landing pages are towards the end of the user flow.  Your blog posts and content on your website pages are going to draw the user in, where we have CTAs to our landing pages to  bring visitors into the funnel.  The idea that a campaign would consist of a few blog posts, some ctas, and a landing page/offer and a confirmation page, so you would want your entry points to a campaign or offer to be the pages that rank.

I’ll add a blog post from Darmesh (ceo of HubSpot) here: <https://inbound.org/blog/the-sub-domain-vs-sub-directory-seo-debate-explained-in-one-flow-chart>

i don’t really wanna do the proxy at all. 
was hoping i’d as my question and someone would be like “why don’t you just ___” and I’d be like :bulb: brilliant thanks
LOL

not to start a scary thread, but I believe you want your blog & your pillar pages on same domain, and ideally root domain. i believe that when they’re not… domain authority is not transferred (regardless of what matt says, there’s just data showing otherwise) and the subdomain you’re building doesn’t let the primary domain get full credit. Pages in primary domain do not get lift (like at all in my experience) when inbound is on a subdomain.
reserve right to delete that comment ^ if subdomain war starts after writing :slightly_smiling_face:
LOL It is ideal.
But most of our clients should focus on quality content
the rest will follow
<@U2SJA29B4> not ideal but isnt there a wordpress plugin that pulls HubSpot blogs into its database?
not sure, i could just publish in wordpress directly. goal is to skip that tool.. but i do feel you on the idea.

I've been running into an issue for the last couple of days where stylesheets I reference in content settings just randomly stop loading.  I can usually get them to load again by deleting, saving, re-adding, and re-saving (annoying).  Anyone else having this issue?

This is driving me nuts...  I reference a stylesheet running on localhost when I'm building sites so I can run my styles through a gulp task.  Half my afternoon has been taken up trying to figure out why stylesheets are only loading intermittently.
Hi <@U54TVT3C1> do you have any more detail? Which stylesheets are not loading? Have you contacted support?
Hi jeff, so here's the story.  I've got a couple links that I'm adding to the `<head>` via content settings that aren't showing up in the `<head>` at page level
<@U54TVT3C1> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U54TVT3C1/F8FLCHDSR/screen_shot_2017-12-15_at_2.55.31_pm.png|Screen Shot 2017-12-15 at 2.55.31 PM.png>
<@U54TVT3C1> uploaded a file: <https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/files/U54TVT3C1/F8GC81S78/screen_shot_2017-12-15_at_2.57.30_pm.png|Screen Shot 2017-12-15 at 2.57.30 PM.png>

I've noticed a little further down the head tag that there's the following message: `<!-- The style tag has been deprecated. Attached stylesheets are included in the required_head_tags page variable. -->`
I haven't contacted support yet, but I will be shortly
is there a particular page/layout you’re testing with this?
Just a page I've got under construction.
but across all my pages, the link to localhost is no longer loading
Just created a new page using the vast homepage template and both stylesheets showed up for a second in the head, but disappeared when I reloaded the page.
can you share the link of the page?
<http://paymedia-3805695.hs-sites.com/-temporary-slug-a9786411-75f0-4abc-82cd-6c0b31744f6c?hs_preview=KOiuHHNM-5479653770>
Ok, we see the issue. It’s unusual to load from localhost, but you can get around the CSS optimization by putting &hsDebug in your query string while in development mode
we’ll fix it so it doesn’t mess with localhost urls
hmm... ok.  &hsDebug fixed the issue for me for now.  Thanks!
lol... and it's broken again

<@U54TVT3C1> are you loading your css from localhost ? Using something to auto refresh and everything?I have thought about doing that and then once a page is complete and  approved move it to the live css file.

<@U25PYL3Q8> we build almost exclusively in local-hubl-server, so we've got a gulp task with browser sync set up for auto-refresh that works great for that.  We then move our page templates over to HubSpot to put finishing touches on (mostly styling any custom modules, because it's a huge pain to create them as JSON objects in local-hubl-server and then build them again in HubSpot).
Do you find that you save time using local hubl server ?

No auto-refresh for the pages in HubSpot, but it's still nice to be able to reference your localhost stylesheet while quickly making changes in your preferred code editor, and then dump the finalized css into a file on HubSpot.

I've personally found it to be significantly faster, but mostly because I can use my preferred tooling and workflow instead of writing code in the Design Manager.  We also ran into a few network issues not too long ago, and waiting for page refresh 1000+ times a day was killing me
It's great to have the flexibility to build without needing an internet connection 100% of the time.  Sometimes I just want to style a page while sitting in a park.
Oh... also, it's nice to be able to create git repos for all our themes.  Makes collaborative projects much much easier.

I guess I do a mix of this. I have all my stuff that I make in all my tooling, then copy / paste into HubSpot. most pages I write all the html at once, then paste in, then style. I adjust in chrome tools and put into my sass file. After I get a little deep into it I make sure to upload and recheck everything i’ve worked on

I wonder if I could change up my hs page to use localhost — then change my gulp to refresh the current page I was on — would eliminate the need to use devtools unless I was fiddling with something and unsure on
That sounds like a pretty cool idea
do you see your workflow at all changing with the new module editor?
I think it will have to be a wait and see sort of thing.  Haven't had a chance to take it for a spin yet.  They IDE sounds nice, but I really love writing SASS
and automatic vendor-prefixing is a must have for me
loving the new IDE probably about 50% more efficient then when building out vs the old editor
Can we quote you on that? :grinning:

I got myself a little gulp setup that allows me to work more “modularly” — it compiles the file I’m working on and no others. throws mixins out the window, but I was thinking I could build a global project file that has my global styling, and then change the way modules folder builds out to use the more modular so I can work on those styles for the module
AND, since I am thinking about it — I could use this gulp-clipboard
<https://www.npmjs.com/package/gulp-clipboard>
Which would, in theory, copy the file I’m working on into the clipboard so I could, in theory, just paste it into the module css editor
absolutely
